question_text: A 29-year-old man is evaluated for the skin lesions shown. He works as a professional landscaper.
question_stem: Which of the following infections is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis in this patient is sporotrichosis, which is caused by the fungus Sporothrix schenckii (Option D). S. schenckii lives in soil, moss, or other organic material frequently used in gardening and landscaping. The most common presentation of sporotrichosis is lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. The primary lesion is located at the site of inoculation (in this case, over the fourth metacarpophalangeal joint) and consists of an ulcerated nodule. Similar lesions occur proximally along the lymphatics (in this case, up the arm).Sporotrichosis can also present as a plaque-like or verrucous-like lesion that typically appears on the face. Extracutaneous infection (osteoarticular, pulmonary, ocular, or disseminated) can occur rarely in immunocompromised hosts.
